title: How to Grow a Sustainable Garden

steps.headline: Choose a planting spot that drains quickly after rain or watering.
steps.description: If you’re going to be watering your garden with a hose, make sure the spot you choose to start planting is reachable by the hose. Avoid choosing a spot in your yard that collects water when it rains—you want well-draining soil. You can always use a watering can to water your plants as well. To find out if your soil is well-draining, dig a hole that's 1 foot (0.30 m) deep and 1 foot (0.30 m) wide. Fill the hole with water and time how long it takes to drain—if it takes less than 30 minutes, the soil drains properly. If your soil is of poor quality, you can buy nutrient-rich, well-draining soil at a garden store or online.

steps.headline: Use a shovel to loosen rocks and soil before planting.
steps.description: You want your soil to be soft and broken up enough for roots to be able to flourish. Use a shovel or rake to loosen the soil so that it's not caked together, digging into the soil in all different directions. Remove any particularly large rocks from the area. Loosen the soil to about 1 foot (30 cm) in depth.

steps.headline: Amend your soil with nutrient-rich compost.
steps.description: You can buy soil at a gardening store that is well-draining and rich with nutrients, if desired. You could also add in your own compost if you've started creating some. Spread the rich soil evenly throughout your planting area. Create a layer of soil or compost that's at least 4 inches (10 cm) thick. If your soil is made up of heavy clay, till the compost into the soil to improve drainage.

steps.headline: Plant seeds or young plants in squares instead of rows.
steps.description: Divide your garden into squares to create a grid, measuring each square to be 12 by 12 inches (30 by 30 cm). When you go to plant the seeds, read the back of the package where it says something like “space after thinning” to find out how far apart to spread the seeds in the square. For example, if your lettuce seeds need to be 6 inches (15 cm) apart from one another to grow properly, divide your square into 4 sections and put a seed in the middle of each section. Planting in squares instead of rows will help conserve energy and space since the seeds are planted closer together.

steps.headline: Design pathways between your plants so that you’re able to care for them.
steps.description: You may have a great grid system for your garden, but make sure you plan out a way to reach all of your plants. You’ll want to easily water, prune, and check up on them without trampling on other plants. This is more important for larger gardens. If you can reach the middle of your garden by standing on the outskirts, you don’t need to design pathways in the middle. The pathway just needs to be big enough for you to walk—how wide you make it is up to you.

steps.headline: Place plants in areas that correspond to the amount of sunlight they need.
steps.description: Some plants love shade and will dry out if they’re in constant direct sunlight, while other plants need lots of sun to thrive. Consider each plant’s sunlight needs when deciding where to place them. For example, you can place a plant that likes shade under a taller plant that loves the sun—the taller plant will provide a shadow to rest in for the shade-loving plant. Plants that need full sun should be planted in a spot that gets at least 6-8 hours of sunlight a day.

steps.headline: Start with a small garden until you gain more experience.
steps.description: Planting too many plants before you know what you’re doing will leave you feeling overwhelmed, and your plants might not thrive as well. Start off with a small garden of 2 or 3 different types of plants, learn how to grow these, and expand your garden later on. A small garden will make watering and maintenance much easier. You can plant as many of the 2 or 3 types of plants as you'd like—you might start off by planting 5 or 6, or plant the entire seed packet, depending on how much space you have available.

steps.headline: Learn which plants can be planted next to one another.
steps.description: Sometimes placing certain plants next to each other will help keep bugs away, while other times the plants will hinder each other’s growth. Go online to find plant compatibility charts that will tell you which plants grow well next to each other, and which ones don’t. For example, kale grows well next to cabbage and potatoes, but it should be kept away from strawberries and tomatoes. Peppers are compatible with basil, onions, spinach, and tomatoes, but should not be planted near beans. Asparagus can be planted next to any plant, but it particularly thrives next to basil, lettuce, spinach, tomatoes, beets, and parsley. Try planting melons next to corn, peas, radishes, tomatoes, or sunflowers. Keep them away from cucumbers and potatoes.

steps.headline: Save money by purchasing seeds instead of plants.
steps.description: It may seem like more work to start growing your plants from seeds, but it’s much more cost-efficient. Buy a package of seeds that you’d like to start planting, and you’ll be able to plant lots of potential plants for a very low price. A package of seeds typically costs anywhere from a few cents to a few dollars, and you'll receive many little seeds. Try to choose seeds from local companies—these seeds will be better adapted to growing in your climate.

steps.headline: Pick out plants you like to eat to create a food source.
steps.description: You’re not going to be excited to grow plants that you’re not interested in, so choose plants that you or your family enjoys eating. You’ll be more invested in these plants and will be provided with yummy food once they’ve grown. If you like peppers, beets, or eggplants, these are great options to start with since they’re easy and grow quickly.

steps.headline: Plant native species for easily-maintained plants.
steps.description: These are plants that thrive where you live—they grow well in the climate, specific soil, and amount of rain you typically get. Visit your local nursery or garden store to ask which plants are natives, or you can do a quick search online. Native species require a lot less work to grow and need less water since they’re used to the climate. Native species will also attract local bees, butterflies, and other wildlife more easily.

steps.headline: Choose small perennials to save money and watch them grow.
steps.description: Perennials are a smart investment since they’ll bloom year after year once you plant them. Purchase perennials that are young and small—these are cheaper than big ones, and the small perennials will end up growing just as large. You can find perennials at your local home improvement store or nursery.

steps.headline: Grow your plants according to the seasons.
steps.description: Knowing which seasons are best for growing certain plants will give you a super healthy, thriving garden. By growing plants seasonally, you’ll be able to plant something different after a crop’s season is over. For example, try planting greens or lettuce in the spring, and then tomatoes and peppers in the summer.

steps.headline: Include flowers in your garden to attract helpful insects.
steps.description: The flowers will draw in insects that will actually help your garden grow, and might even eat other insects that would harm your garden. Plant flowers like marigolds or sweet alyssum to attract beneficial insects. If you spend a lot of time outside and are worried about insects like bees being around often, you might consider planting these flowers farther away.

steps.headline: Make your lawn smaller.
steps.description: This will cut down on the amount of water you use to keep your grass healthy, and you’ll spend less time mowing it. Look for areas in your lawn that don’t grow grass well or are difficult to reach, and consider covering these areas with stones, mulch, shrubs, or plants that will thrive there. For example, if you have a ditch in your yard, consider putting soil in it and planting a few flowers.

steps.headline: Compost all of your leftover food and garden waste.
steps.description: All of those scraps left over from dinner, or the clippings you snipped off of your plants, can go together in a compost. You can have a small can in the kitchen to put food scraps in, or you can start your compost outside if you think you’ll have lots. Composting does take a while, so be prepared to wait roughly a year to be able to use it in your garden.

steps.headline: Collect rainwater to use for watering your plants.
steps.description: Growing a healthy garden will take a sufficient amount of water, but not all of it needs to come from your sink or garden hose. Use rain barrels to collect large amounts of water. If you don’t have rain barrels, you can use things around the house, such as pots, buckets, or even inflatable swimming pools. Place plants that require more water near gutter downspouts. These downspouts will direct the water to these plants.

steps.headline: Mulch your garden to help the soil retain moisture.
steps.description: Choose a mulch that you like, or make your own, and cover the soil with a 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) layer of it. This will help keep the soil nice and moist after it’s watered, and will also help prevent weeds. Mulch can be made of wood chips, sawdust, leaves, bark, and even newspaper.

steps.headline: Save seeds so that you can plant them again later on.
steps.description: If you’re growing something that provides seeds at the end of the season, save these seeds to plant again later. Dry the seeds and store them in a protected, dry place. Let the seeds dry out before putting them in a container or plastic bag for safe keeping.

steps.headline: Conserve water by controlling water runoff.
steps.description: Use drip irrigation or soaker hoses to help save water in your garden. If you use a sprinkler system, make sure it isn’t watering unnecessary things, such as the sidewalk or driveway. Drip irrigation uses lengths of rubber hose with small holes punched in the side to distribute water along the roots of the plants. You can either make your own hoses or purchase a drip irrigation system.
